Probabilistic Heuristics for Disseminating Information in Networks

Alexandre O. Stauffer
Valmir C. Barbosa

Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
Programa de Engenharia de Sistemas e Computação, COPPE
Caixa Postal 68511
21941-972 Rio de Janeiro - RJ, Brazil Corresponding author (valmir@cos.ufrj.br).
Abstract

We study the problem of disseminating a piece of information through all the nodes of a network, given that it is known originally only to a single node. In the absence of any structural knowledge on the network other than the nodes’ neighborhoods, this problem is traditionally solved by flooding all the network’s edges. We analyze a recently introduced probabilistic algorithm for flooding and give an alternative probabilistic heuristic that can lead to some cost-effective improvements, like better trade-offs between the message and time complexities involved. We analyze the two algorithms both mathematically and by means of simulations, always within a random-graph framework and considering relevant node-degree distributions.


Keywords: Random networks, Probabilistic flooding, Heuristic flooding.

1 Introduction

A network can be viewed as an undirected graph G=(NG,EG)𝐺subscript𝑁𝐺subscript𝐸𝐺G=(N_{G},E_{G})italic_G = ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with n=|NG|𝑛subscript𝑁𝐺n=|N_{G}|italic_n = | italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | nodes and m=|EG|𝑚subscript𝐸𝐺m=|E_{G}|italic_m = | italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | edges, in which the existence of an edge (u,v)𝑢𝑣\left(u,v\right)( italic_u , italic_v ) represents the possibility of bidirectional communication between nodes u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v. We consider the problem of disseminating a piece of information, referred to as I𝐼Iitalic_I, to all the nodes of the network, given that initially only one node, called the originator, has it.

A traditional algorithm to disseminate information in networks when nodes know their immediate neighborhoods and nothing else is what we call uninformed flooding [16], in allusion to the fact that its actions do in no way take into account the structure of the network or any of its properties. In this algorithm, the originator starts by sending I𝐼Iitalic_I to its neighbors; when receiving I𝐼Iitalic_I for the first time, each of the other nodes forwards it to its own neighbors. This algorithm has message complexity of Θ⁢(m)Θ𝑚\Theta(m)roman_Θ ( italic_m ), as exactly two messages are transmitted on each edge, and worst-case time complexity of O⁢(n)𝑂𝑛O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ), the latter related to the customary message-passing causal chains of distributed computing under full asynchronism [3]. Also, when edges can be assumed to have approximately equal delays associated with them, the algorithm’s average waiting time, which is the average time for a node to receive I𝐼Iitalic_I, is given by the average distance from the originator in the network, that is, the average number of edges on the shortest paths between the originator and each of the other nodes.

Our interest in this paper is to study the trade-off between the message complexity and the average waiting time when I𝐼Iitalic_I is no longer forwarded deterministically to all of a node’s neighbors, but rather is sent as the result of probabilistic decisions. Our initial motivation has been the recent introduction of probabilistic flooding [2], which prescribes for each node that it forward I𝐼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors with fixed probability p𝑝pitalic_p. Probabilistic flooding is then also “uninformed,” constituting essentially a simple stochastic generalization of the aforementioned (deterministic) uninformed flooding. We introduce in Section 2 the alternative that we call heuristic flooding, which is also probabilistic in nature but, unlike probabilistic flooding, takes the network’s structure into account insofar as it can be inferred from the nodes’ immediate neighborhoods.

Naturally, flooding the network with copies of I𝐼Iitalic_I that are propagated probabilistically does not ensure that all nodes will eventually receive a copy. There do exist applications, however, that may benefit from the aforementioned trade-off even in the absence of such delivery guarantees. We refer the reader to [2] and to the references therein for examples in the area of peer-to-peer computing when I𝐼Iitalic_I is interpreted as a query and the flooding as a search.

We base our analyses of both algorithms on the generating functions of discrete probability distributions [10]. The formalism we utilize is the one laid down in [15], whose details are briefly reviewed and extended in Section 3. Our analyses are also based on what we call a flooding digraph, which is a random directed subgraph of the network. In Section 4, we introduce this subgraph and use it to obtain our analytical results.

All our analyses are carried out in the framework of random graphs [1]. Within this framework, we give special attention to random graphs whose node degrees are either Poisson-distributed or distributed according to a power law. The former arise in the classic context of Erdős and Rényi [7], while the latter have recently been found to be representative of networks like the Internet and the WWW [8, 12, 1]. Simulation results are given in Section 5 for these models of random graphs.

A comparative study of the two probabilistic approaches is given in Section 6, and concluding remarks in Section 7.

2 Heuristic flooding

In probabilistic flooding, each node decides whether to send I𝐼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors based on a fixed probability parameter p𝑝pitalic_p. As a consequence, a node with a small degree has a smaller probability of receiving the information than a node with a large degree. Given a node u𝑢uitalic_u and one of its neighbors v𝑣vitalic_v, if a𝑎aitalic_a is the degree of u𝑢uitalic_u and b𝑏bitalic_b the degree of v𝑣vitalic_v, our new heuristic flooding is based on a function h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) representing the probability that node u𝑢uitalic_u sends I𝐼Iitalic_I to node v𝑣vitalic_v. Intuitively, h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is expected to have a larger value when at least one of a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b is small than when they are both large, thus attempting to compensate for the inherent drawback of probabilistic flooding that we just mentioned, and also to reflect the understanding that a small a𝑎aitalic_a may signify the existence of insufficient alternative routes for v𝑣vitalic_v to ultimately receive I𝐼Iitalic_I from u𝑢uitalic_u even when b𝑏bitalic_b is large.

Ideally, an accurate heuristic function would require some knowledge about the topology of the network beyond the nodes’ immediate neighborhoods; realistically, however, a node can only be assumed to have information about its own neighbors. For this reason, heuristic flooding is defined to operate under the assumption by each node u𝑢uitalic_u that a neighboring node v𝑣vitalic_v can only receive the information from min⁡{a,b}𝑎𝑏\min\left\{a,b\right\}roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } of v𝑣vitalic_v’s own neighbors, for each one with equal probability h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ), where a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b are the degrees of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, respectively. In other words, there are two sides to our assumption. One side is that, if u𝑢uitalic_u decides not to forward I𝐼Iitalic_I to v𝑣vitalic_v, then v𝑣vitalic_v can still receive I𝐼Iitalic_I from min⁡{a,b}−1𝑎𝑏1\min\left\{a,b\right\}-1roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } - 1 of its neighbors, if any, in each case with the same probability h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ). The other side of the assumption is that the other b−min⁡{a,b}𝑏𝑎𝑏b-\min\left\{a,b\right\}italic_b - roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } neighbors of v𝑣vitalic_v, if any, are unable to receive I𝐼Iitalic_I if v𝑣vitalic_v does not send it to them.

If we let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α stand for the desired probability that a node receives the information being broadcast, then, from the perspective of node u𝑢uitalic_u upon deciding whether to send the information to its neighbor v𝑣vitalic_v, the probability that v𝑣vitalic_v does not receive the information (that is, 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha1 - italic_α) can be expressed as

1−α=[1−α+α⁢(1−h⁢(a,b))]min⁡{a,b}.1𝛼superscriptdelimited-[]1𝛼𝛼1ℎ𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑏1-\alpha=\left[1-\alpha+\alpha\left(1-h(a,b)\right)\right]^{\min\left\{a,b\right\}}.1 - italic_α = [ 1 - italic_α + italic_α ( 1 - italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (1)

This expression indicates that v𝑣vitalic_v does not receive the information if and only if, for each of the min⁡{a,b}𝑎𝑏\min\left\{a,b\right\}roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } neighbors that the assumption says could send the information to it, either that neighbor has not itself received the information (with probability 1−α1𝛼1-\alpha1 - italic_α) or it has but decided not to forward it to v𝑣vitalic_v (with probability α⁢(1−h⁢(a,b))𝛼1ℎ𝑎𝑏\alpha\left(1-h(a,b)\right)italic_α ( 1 - italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) )). Hence,

h⁢(a,b)=1−(1−α)1/min⁡{a,b}α.ℎ𝑎𝑏1superscript1𝛼1𝑎𝑏𝛼h(a,b)=\frac{1-\left(1-\alpha\right)^{1/\min\left\{a,b\right\}}}{\alpha}.italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) = divide start_ARG 1 - ( 1 - italic_α ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG . (2)

This heuristic function has the property that, when both a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b are large, h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is small, which corresponds to the intuition that there may exist other paths along which v𝑣vitalic_v can receive I𝐼Iitalic_I, so it may not be essential that u𝑢uitalic_u sends it to v𝑣vitalic_v. On the other hand, when at least one of a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b is small, then h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is large. In particular, when at least one of a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b is equal to 1111, that is, min⁡{a,b}=1𝑎𝑏1\min\left\{a,b\right\}=1roman_min { italic_a , italic_b } = 1, then h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) is also 1111. 3 The generating-function formalism

Henceforth, G𝐺Gitalic_G is viewed as a random graph whose nodes all have degrees that are independent of one another and distributed identically to a random variable KGsubscript𝐾𝐺K_{G}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The nodes of G𝐺Gitalic_G are assumed to be interconnected at random given their degrees, so the degrees of any two adjacent nodes remain independent. The results from [15] reviewed in Section 3.1, and also their extensions in Section 3.2, hold in the limiting case of a formally infinite number of nodes.

4 Mathematical analysis

We start by considering a generic probabilistic algorithm for disseminating a piece of information I𝐼Iitalic_I on the network represented by G𝐺Gitalic_G. In this algorithm, when a node of degree a𝑎aitalic_a receives I𝐼Iitalic_I for the first time, it forwards I𝐼Iitalic_I to each of its neighbors with probability f⁢(a,b)𝑓𝑎𝑏f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ), where b𝑏bitalic_b is the degree of the prospective recipient. This process induces the appearance of a random directed subgraph F=(NF,EF)𝐹subscript𝑁𝐹subscript𝐸𝐹F=(N_{F},E_{F})italic_F = ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of G𝐺Gitalic_G that we call the flooding digraph. This digraph has the same nodes as G𝐺Gitalic_G (that is, VF=VGsubscript𝑉𝐹subscript𝑉𝐺V_{F}=V_{G}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and its edges are such that, for (u,v)∈EG𝑢𝑣subscript𝐸𝐺(u,v)\in E_{G}( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the directed edge (u→v)→𝑢𝑣(u\to v)( italic_u → italic_v ) exists in EFsubscript𝐸𝐹E_{F}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability f⁢(a,b)𝑓𝑎𝑏f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ), given that a𝑎aitalic_a and b𝑏bitalic_b are the degrees of nodes u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v in G𝐺Gitalic_G, respectively.

Clearly, this generic algorithm can stand for both probabilistic flooding and heuristic flooding. In the former case, f⁢(a,b)=p𝑓𝑎𝑏𝑝f(a,b)=pitalic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ) = italic_p regardless of a𝑎aitalic_a or b𝑏bitalic_b; in the latter, f⁢(a,b)𝑓𝑎𝑏f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ) is the heuristic function h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) given by (2). As probabilistic flooding is a special case of heuristic flooding, for the remainder of this section we concentrate solely on the latter and use the h⁢(a,b)ℎ𝑎𝑏h(a,b)italic_h ( italic_a , italic_b ) of (2) instead of f⁢(a,b)𝑓𝑎𝑏f(a,b)italic_f ( italic_a , italic_b ).

4.1 Random digraphs

Let us first review some of the properties of random digraphs in general and also how they apply to the case of F𝐹Fitalic_F.

For u𝑢uitalic_u a node of a digraph, its in-neighbors are those nodes from which an edge exists directed toward u𝑢uitalic_u; its out-neighbors are those nodes toward which an edge exists directed from u𝑢uitalic_u. Moreover, a node is an r𝑟ritalic_r-in-neighbor of u𝑢uitalic_u if the directed distance from it to u𝑢uitalic_u is r𝑟ritalic_r. Similarly, a node is an r𝑟ritalic_r-out-neighbor of u𝑢uitalic_u if the directed distance from u𝑢uitalic_u to it is r𝑟ritalic_r. When a directed path exists from node u𝑢uitalic_u to node v𝑣vitalic_v, we say that v𝑣vitalic_v is reachable from u𝑢uitalic_u (equivalently, u𝑢uitalic_u reaches v𝑣vitalic_v).

A connected component of the undirected graph that underlies a digraph (i.e., the graph that we obtain when edge directions are ignored) is called a weakly connected component of the digraph. Thus a digraph has a size-Θ⁢(n)Θ𝑛\Theta(n)roman_Θ ( italic_n ) weakly connected component, referred to as the giant weakly connected component (GWCC), if and only if the undirected graph that underlies it has a GCC.

The GWCC of a digraph has four distinguished types of sub-digraphs. In the case of F𝐹Fitalic_F, they are as illustrated in Figure 2 and such that:

  • •

    The giant strongly connected component (GSCC) is the largest sub-digraph of the GWCC that is maximal with respect to the property that any of its nodes is reachable from any other.

  • •

    The giant in-component (GIN), comprising a fraction θFinsubscriptsuperscript𝜃in𝐹\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of G𝐺Gitalic_G (or a fraction θFin/θGsubscriptsuperscript𝜃in𝐹subscript𝜃𝐺\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of the GCC of G𝐺Gitalic_G), contains all the nodes that can reach the GSCC (including, by definition, those of the GSCC).

  • •

    The giant out-component (GOUT), comprising a fraction θFoutsubscriptsuperscript𝜃out𝐹\theta^{\textrm{out}}_{F}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of G𝐺Gitalic_G (or a fraction θFout/θGsubscriptsuperscript𝜃out𝐹subscript𝜃𝐺\theta^{\textrm{out}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT out end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the nodes of the GCC of G𝐺Gitalic_G), contains all the nodes that are reachable from the GSCC (including, by definition, those of the GSCC).

  • •

    Each of the so-called tendrils consists of some of the remaining nodes [6].

4.2 Number of nodes reached

We now consider the expected fraction of nodes of G𝐺Gitalic_G that receive I𝐼Iitalic_I in heuristic flooding. Recall that, by assumption, G𝐺Gitalic_G almost surely has a GCC and the originator is one of the nodes of the GCC. Two cases must be considered. The first case corresponds to the originator being outside the GIN, belonging therefore either to the portion of the GOUT that does not intersect the GSCC or to a tendril. This case happens with probability 1−θFin/θG1subscriptsuperscript𝜃in𝐹subscript𝜃𝐺1-\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}1 - italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and leads to a negligibly small number of nodes reached by the flooding. The second case is the case in which the originator is inside the GIN. It occurs with probability θFin/θGsubscriptsuperscript𝜃in𝐹subscript𝜃𝐺\theta^{\textrm{in}}_{F}/\theta_{G}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the flooding necessarily reaches all the nodes of the GOUT. 4.4 Average waiting time

As we mentioned in Section 1, assessing a distributed algorithm’s time-related complexities in a fully general asynchronous setting requires that message-passing causal chains be considered [3]. In our current context, and taking into account our current knowledge of random graphs and their analysis, obtaining accurate analytical estimates of those complexities for flooding seems infeasible. Our choice is then to settle for a less general form of asynchronism in which the delay associated with the delivery of a message over an edge of G𝐺Gitalic_G is roughly constant for all of G𝐺Gitalic_G’s edges. In this case, the waiting time before a node is reached by a flooding can be taken to be proportional to the distance in G𝐺Gitalic_G from the originator to that node.

In order to compare the expected waiting time of heuristic flooding with that of uninformed flooding, we calculate the ratio Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the expected path length from the originator in F𝐹Fitalic_F to the expected path length from the originator in G𝐺Gitalic_G. Recall that, even though we employ the common denomination as a path, in the case of F𝐹Fitalic_F paths are directed, while in G𝐺Gitalic_G they are undirected.

For uninformed flooding with originator inside the GCC, the expected path length from the originator can be approximated by LGCCsubscript𝐿GCCL_{\textrm{GCC}}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GCC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as in (22). In order to obtain the corresponding expression for heuristic flooding, we proceed as we did for Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and consider only the case in which the originator is inside the GIN, which occurs with probability θFin/θGsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝐹insubscript𝜃𝐺\theta_{F}^{\textrm{in}}/\theta_{G}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also assume that only the nodes inside the GOUT can be reached by the flooding. 5 Simulation results

In our simulations we have used random graphs as models for networks [1]. The network may thus not be connected, so simulations have only been carried out inside the largest connected component of the random graph. Also, in order to ensure that such a component encompasses a large number of nodes, we have restricted ourselves to graphs for which a GCC is almost surely guaranteed to exist. Our interest has been to analyze Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and to this end we have simulated probabilistic flooding for p=0.30𝑝0.30p=0.30italic_p = 0.30, 0.600.600.600.60, 0.900.900.900.90 and heuristic flooding for α=0.90𝛼0.90\alpha=0.90italic_α = 0.90, 0.950.950.950.95, 0.990.990.990.99.

We have considered two random-graph models. In the first model G𝐺Gitalic_G is generated on n𝑛nitalic_n nodes by creating an edge between any two distinct nodes with fixed probability z/(n−1)𝑧𝑛1z/(n-1)italic_z / ( italic_n - 1 ) for suitable z𝑧zitalic_z. A node in the resulting graph has degree a𝑎aitalic_a with the Poisson probability of mean z𝑧zitalic_z [4], that is, PG⁢(a)=e−z⁢za/a!subscript𝑃𝐺𝑎superscript𝑒𝑧superscript𝑧𝑎𝑎P_{G}(a)=e^{-z}z^{a}/a!italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_a !. Also, we have ZG=zsubscript𝑍𝐺𝑧Z_{G}=zitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_z and ⟨KG2⟩=z2+zdelimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝐾𝐺2superscript𝑧2𝑧\left<K_{G}^{2}\right>=z^{2}+z⟨ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ = italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_z, which by (6) implies that we need z>1𝑧1z>1italic_z > 1 for the GCC to almost surely exist.

Figure 3 shows the results obtained by simulating probabilistic and heuristic flooding on random graphs with Poisson-distributed degrees for n=10000𝑛10000n=10000italic_n = 10000 and z𝑧zitalic_z varying from 1111 to 10101010. For each value of z𝑧zitalic_z, the simulation consisted of generating 15151515 random graphs and, for each one, doing 1000100010001000 instances of each type of flooding (uninformed, probabilistic, and heuristic), each from a randomly chosen node inside the GCC. The simulation results are given as averages of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the 15000 samples. Notice first of all that agreement between simulation and analytical results is very good throughout, with a slight deviation only in parts (c) and (f) of the figure. Such deviations are attributed to the various approximations of Section 4.4. Note also that both probabilistic and heuristic flooding do indeed improve on uninformed flooding as far as the number of messages used is concerned (Pm<1subscript𝑃m1P_{\textrm{m}}<1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1), but nearly always at the expense of larger waiting times (Pt>1subscript𝑃t1P_{\textrm{t}}>1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 1).

The results for probabilistic flooding (Figure 3(a–c)) show that, given a value of p𝑝pitalic_p, there exists a value of z𝑧zitalic_z above which nearly all the nodes of the network are reached by the flooding. If we require Pn≥0.99subscript𝑃n0.99P_{\textrm{n}}\geq 0.99italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.99, then the threshold values for z𝑧zitalic_z are z=5𝑧5z=5italic_z = 5 for p=0.90𝑝0.90p=0.90italic_p = 0.90 and z=9𝑧9z=9italic_z = 9 for p=0.60𝑝0.60p=0.60italic_p = 0.60. For p=0.30𝑝0.30p=0.30italic_p = 0.30 the threshold is greater than 10101010. The plots for Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT show that Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases with z𝑧zitalic_z roughly until these thresholds are reached, remaining constant and approximately equal to p𝑝pitalic_p from there onward. The plots for Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT show a similar but not identical behavior: like Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT often increases roughly until the thresholds are reached; unlike Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT starts to decrease slightly as z𝑧zitalic_z is further increased onward. All the plots show that Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have value 00 when z𝑧zitalic_z is near 1111. This happens because, although the network is above the phase transition that gives rise to the GCC of G𝐺Gitalic_G with high probability for any z>1𝑧1z>1italic_z > 1, for z𝑧zitalic_z sufficiently near 1111 the flooding digraph F𝐹Fitalic_F is still below the phase transition at which the GIN and the GOUT appear (since F𝐹Fitalic_F is a directed subgraph of G𝐺Gitalic_G), so they do not yet exist.

In the case of heuristic flooding (Figure 3(d–f)), the results show that Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT flattens out much earlier than probabilistic flooding to a value that depends on α𝛼\alphaitalic_α. This value is about 0.990.990.990.99 for α=0.99𝛼0.99\alpha=0.99italic_α = 0.99, 0.940.940.940.94 for α=0.95𝛼0.95\alpha=0.95italic_α = 0.95, and 0.860.860.860.86 for α=0.90𝛼0.90\alpha=0.90italic_α = 0.90. The value of Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, in turn, increases sharply until approximately the value at which the flattening of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occurs. Past this value, Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is seen to decrease continually, which indicates the desirable property that, given a fixed Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a progressively smaller fraction of messages is needed as the average degree increases. In contrast, Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases onward through the higher values of z𝑧zitalic_z. This occurs because heuristic flooding tends to send messages on relatively longer paths, avoiding as it does the sending of messages between high-degree nodes.

The second random-graph model we have considered is the one in which degrees are distributed according to a power law. Generation of a random graph with degrees thus distributed can be achieved in two phases. First, the degrees a1,a2,…,ansubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2…subscript𝑎𝑛a_{1},a_{2},\ldots,a_{n}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the n𝑛nitalic_n nodes, constituting the graph’s so-called degree sequence, are sampled from the power-law distribution and ∑i=1naisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT labeled balls are put inside an imaginary urn.111If ∑i=1naisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT turns out to be odd, the degree sampling is repeated until an even sum is obtained. For 1≤i≤n1𝑖𝑛1\leq i\leq n1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_n, label i𝑖iitalic_i is given to exactly aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT balls. In the second phase, a pair of balls (labeled, say, u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v) is picked from the urn at random and an edge (u,v)𝑢𝑣(u,v)( italic_u , italic_v ) is added to the graph. This process is repeated until the urn becomes empty. This algorithm clearly generates a multigraph (a graph in which multiple edges and self-loops are allowed to exist), but the resulting graph is consistent with the model used in our analysis, where we assumed edge independence throughout. Furthermore, even though there are other algorithms to generate random graphs with a given degree sequence [13, 9], it is still unclear how to use them within reasonable time bounds. The fact that multiple edges or self-loops may now exist in G𝐺Gitalic_G has direct impact on how the various flooding algorithms are simulated. Specifically, a node no longer considers whether to forward the information it receives for the first time to each of its neighbors, but rather whether to forward it on each of the edges that are incident to it in G𝐺Gitalic_G.

Figure 4 shows the results obtained by simulating the three flooding methods on random graphs with power-law-distributed degrees for n=10000𝑛10000n=10000italic_n = 10000 and τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ varying from 2222 to 3333. For each value of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, the simulation consists of generating 300300300300 random graphs and, for each one, proceeding exactly as indicated for the Poisson case. First notice, again as in the Poisson case, that agreement between simulation and analytical results is very good for Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, however, the situation is different. Under a power-law distribution for node degrees, expressions like (21) and (46), respectively for ZGCC(2)superscriptsubscript𝑍GCC2Z_{\textrm{GCC}}^{(2)}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GCC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ZGOUT−(2)superscriptsubscript𝑍GOUT2Z_{\textrm{GOUT}}^{-(2)}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GOUT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, are known to be problematic [15], and indeed the calculations do not converge and lead to wrong values for LGCCsubscript𝐿GCCL_{\textrm{GCC}}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GCC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and LGOUT−superscriptsubscript𝐿GOUTL_{\textrm{GOUT}}^{-}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GOUT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Even so, it is curious to note that for probabilistic flooding the two errors seem to compensate each other somehow and the prediction for Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT comes close to the simulation results, as shown in part (c) of the figure. The case of heuristic flooding, on the other hand, remains lacking a satisfactory analytical prediction (thence none is shown in part (f) of the figure).

Also noteworthy in Figure 4 is the consistent superiority of probabilistic and heuristic flooding over uninformed flooding regarding the number of messages sent (Pm<1subscript𝑃m1P_{\textrm{m}}<1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1). In addition, and contrasting with the Poisson case of Figure 3, the same holds for probabilistic flooding, and for sufficiently large τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ also for heuristic flooding, regarding waiting times (Pt<1subscript𝑃t1P_{\textrm{t}}<1italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1). The price for this, of course, is heavy and reflected on the often poor values of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with the exception of probabilistic flooding with p=0.90𝑝0.90p=0.90italic_p = 0.90 and of heuristic flooding, more or less regardless of the value of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, when τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is near 2222.

Simulation results for probabilistic flooding (Figure 4(a–c)) show that Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT increases when τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ decreases, but the variation is sometimes not really too pronounced. For example, for p=0.90𝑝0.90p=0.90italic_p = 0.90 Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is about 0.600.600.600.60 when τ=3.0𝜏3.0\tau=3.0italic_τ = 3.0 and 0.870.870.870.87 when τ=2.0𝜏2.0\tau=2.0italic_τ = 2.0. Similar observations are true of Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notice, in addition, that unlike the Poisson case there does not seem to exist any interval within the range considered for τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ inside which any of the three indicators becomes approximately constant.

In heuristic flooding (Figure 4(d–f)), the value of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also increases when τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ decreases, but at a faster pace than in the case of probabilistic flooding. The values of Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT display two different kinds of behavior. While to either side of τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4 the value of Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases as τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is moved farther away, Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT falls relatively sharply to the right of τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4 but rises, albeit slowly and with an inversion with respect to the values of α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, to the left. From Figure 4(d), τ≈2.4𝜏2.4\tau\approx 2.4italic_τ ≈ 2.4 appears to coincide with a significant change in the second derivative of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a function of τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ.

6 Probabilistic versus heuristic flooding

In spite of having already obtained results on both types of flooding, we still cannot compare them to each other directly, as the parameter p𝑝pitalic_p of probabilistic flooding has no relation whatsoever to the parameter α𝛼\alphaitalic_α of heuristic flooding. In this section, our strategy to make such a comparison possible is to first simulate heuristic flooding with α=0.99𝛼0.99\alpha=0.99italic_α = 0.99 and then use the resulting value of Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to obtain, via (23), the value of p𝑝pitalic_p for which probabilistic flooding is expected to reach the same fraction of the graph’s nodes.

Our results under this strategy are shown in Figure 5 for the Poisson case. Notice, first, that the strategy seems indeed to be effective, since the plots for Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are practically the same for both types of flooding. For z𝑧zitalic_z right past 1111, all the six plots exhibit an anomaly, which is once again likely due to the fact that, at these values of z𝑧zitalic_z, the phase transition that gives rise to the GIN and the GOUT has not yet taken place.

What is most interesting, though, is the evident trade-off between Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that can be seen in parts (b) and (c) of the figure. Clearly, under the constraint that Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is roughly the same for both probabilistic and heuristic flooding, for z𝑧zitalic_z larger than approximately 2.52.52.52.5, Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significantly larger for probabilistic flooding than it is for heuristic flooding. On the other hand, Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significantly larger for heuristic flooding across practically all the spectrum of z𝑧zitalic_z values that Figure 5 encompasses.

But notwithstanding this trade-off, Figure 5 also suggests that the two types of flooding become more and more similar to each other as z𝑧zitalic_z is increased. In fact, as the nodes’ degrees become larger and G𝐺Gitalic_G more homogeneous (approaching, in the limit, the complete graph on n𝑛nitalic_n nodes), the heuristic function of (2) approaches a small constant and heuristic flooding progressively becomes probabilistic flooding.

The corresponding results for graphs with degrees distributed according to a power law are shown in the plots of Figure 6. Once again, our strategy’s effectiveness is corroborated by part (a) of the figure. Also, parts (b) and (c) reveal the same trade-off between Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ptsubscript𝑃tP_{\textrm{t}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that we observed in the Poisson case, along with a similar tendency, especially in the case of part (b), for the two algorithms to resemble each other as τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is increased toward 3333. The justification for part (b) is that, at these values for τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ, heuristic flooding has a small value for Pnsubscript𝑃nP_{\textrm{n}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (cf. part (a)), one that can be achieved by probabilistic flooding with a value of p𝑝pitalic_p for which Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remains relatively low. As for part (c), increasing τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ toward its higher values makes the occurrence of nodes of very high degree ever less likely. Consequently, heuristic flooding no longer refrains so strongly from sending the information being broadcast to the high-degree nodes of the network. This makes path lengths tend to lean toward those of probabilistic flooding.

But what is especially noteworthy in the power-law case is that the superiority of heuristic flooding in terms of Pmsubscript𝑃mP_{\textrm{m}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes very pronounced as τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ is decreased from roughly τ=2.5𝜏2.5\tau=2.5italic_τ = 2.5. This happens because, under a power law, the graph tends to contain a large set of nodes of small degree, many of them of degree 1111. In order to reach the same number of nodes as heuristic flooding, probabilistic flooding must run with a value for p𝑝pitalic_p that is near 1111, which causes an unnecessarily high number of messages to be sent. Heuristic flooding, in turn, is relatively insensitive to the plethora of low-degree nodes, since it attempts to provide each and every node with the same probability of receiving the information.

7 Conclusions

Flooding a network probabilistically for information dissemination is an attempt at reducing the heavy communications demand that uninformed flooding incurs in terms of how many messages are needed. The drawback, of course, is that the guarantee of network-wide information delivery may be lost. In this paper we started with the recently introduced probabilistic flooding, in which every node forwards the information to all of its neighbors with constant probability.

Then we introduced an alternative technique, called heuristic flooding, which employs degree-based probabilistic decisions at the nodes, aiming at a pre-defined probability, the same for all nodes, that a node receives the information being disseminated. We have also contributed a detailed mathematical analysis of both probabilistic flooding and heuristic flooding, comprising analytical predictions of the techniques’ reachability, their communications requirements, and an indicator related to the time needed for completion of the flooding.

Our extensive simulation results have revealed the two techniques’ main characteristics on random graphs with Poisson- and power-law-distributed degrees. They have also indicated an excellent agreement between theory and experimentation in most cases.

In addition, one final set of simulations designed especially to allow a meaningful comparison between the two flooding techniques demonstrated an interesting trade-off involving them: in general, heuristic flooding outperforms probabilistic flooding in terms of communications requirements, but the opposite holds in terms of the delay required for completion. Curiously, the balance between the two sides of this trade-off is not equally tipped: for example, under a power law with relatively small parameter, the communications-related gain of heuristic flooding over probabilistic flooding significantly surpasses its delay-related loss.
